text: definitely recommend starting your own side project / website that you can experiment on & use as your portfolio once you start ranking

elements.text: definitely recommend starting your own side project / website that you can experiment on & use as your portfolio once you start ranking

text: Another way to switch into it could be to apply for content marketing jobs that include SEO as part of the duties? in a lot of teams it's part of the same thing, and if you wanted to switch to a solely SEO role afterwards at least you would then have something more specific on your resume about it

text: This isn't a framework exactly, but I lived by the commandments in this article when I was content marketer #1 at a startup. It helped me grow a blog to over 100K visitors/month in about a year's time by being consistent and putting a huge emphasis on quality. Hope this helps! <https://review.firstround.com/content-is-eating-the-world-contentlys-ceo-on-winning-at-marketings-fastest-growing-trend>

attachments.title: Content is Eating the World — Contently's CEO on Winning at Marketing's New Hotness
attachments.text: Joe Coleman has been helping companies of all sizes publish quality content for years. Here's his advice for startups as this new marketing trend reaches fever pitch.
attachments.fallback: Content is Eating the World — Contently's CEO on Winning at Marketing's New Hotness

elements.text: This isn't a framework exactly, but I lived by the commandments in this article when I was content marketer #1 at a startup. It helped me grow a blog to over 100K visitors/month in about a year's time by being consistent and putting a huge emphasis on quality. Hope this helps!

text:
I made the transition from content to product marketing about a year ago and it's been a learning curve, but I really like it!

As a Content Lead, I was responsible for planning the editorial calendar, writing briefs, editing long-form blog posts, tracking metrics, optimizing older pieces of content and managing a small team (+ freelancers) to scale content efforts across the blog, video, and social. My goals were around traffic, converting traffic to signups, and (sometimes) the ability to get backlinks (note: I work for a B2C company that heavily relies organic traffic — so no sales team or long sales process).

As a PMM, I run surveys and interview customers to get a deep understanding of their needs, and surface these findings back to the product team to influence both product improvements and new features; improve the customer onboarding experience through post-purchase emails and in-app messages; work on messaging on the website and in-app; create product tutorials, customer webinars, and help content; run cross-functional meetings to better connect the product team to the CS and marketing teams. I also sometimes work on one-off projects related to pricing and packaging, and I'm project-managing a website redesign. Again, my company is small and B2C, so maybe not a typical B2B experience!

This is a great article to help better understand the PMM function, and I highly recommend the PMA's certification as well!

<https://mkt1.substack.com/p/weve-been-defining-product-marketing>

attachments.title: We've been defining product marketing wrong
attachments.text: A guide to product marketing for early-stage startups, includes: list of all product marketing responsibilities & a template to do your own audience analysis.
attachments.fallback: We've been defining product marketing wrong
